utterances: What I will say is that a recent study just came out about the new iPod phone that's planned to come out in June from Apple.
And they are saying that over a - they did a research study; this is done by Solutions Research Group.
And 16 percent of Americans over the age of 12, they say it's approximately 40 million people responded to a survey that they thought an iPod phone would be a great idea for them personally.

But here is the interesting note: 53 percent of likely iPhone buyers would be female, 47 percent male; African-Americans and Hispanics were the two ethnicities that expressed above average interest in this device.

Well, you know what, I'm just waiting for the rap video were some new hit of the week is waiving his phone in the air and, you know, shouting out like you just don't care; then we'll know they've made it in the black market.

Yeah, well, this is getting into this whole sticky issue of what continues to be a sticky issue in the industry when you talk about digital files, and that is digital rights management, otherwise known as DRM.
They use those words quite often, digital rights management.
So there are these issues.
And recently, Steve Jobs, the CEO of Apple, really just lit a fire with a statement saying we as an industry need to get pass this digital rights management stuff.
It is holding the innovation cycle back.
It's holding consumers back.
And his point is that all music should be DRM-free.
And in fact, I believe it's the music group EMI who has now said, yes, Steve, you are actually right, and we're going to now offer our music as free with no digital rights behind that.
So it will be interesting to see if any of the other major music labels follow that lead of EMI.
Well, Mario, as usual, it's been fun.
Thanks.
It's been a pleasure.
Thank you.
Mario Armstrong is NEWS & NOTES tech contributor.
He also covers technology for member stations WYPR and WEAA.
From the studios of NPR West, this is DAY TO DAY.
I'm Alex Cohen.
And I'm Madeleine Brand.
Coming up, 50 years ago nine black students made history when they walked into a Little Rock high school.
And today thousands of United Auto Workers walked off their jobs at GM plants throughout the country.
After months of talks, including all night contract negotiations last night, the UAW and General Motors have not been able to reach an agreement.
NPR reporter Celeste Headlee joins me now.
She's outside GM's Detroit-Hamtramck Assembly plant.
Celeste, at a news conference today the president of the UAW said the union was very disappointed with the way things had been going.
But he also said the two sides will return to the table.
You've been outside this plant now for a while.
What are you hearing from GM workers?
Well, first of all, most of them were very surprised to be on strike today.
Most of them expected that they were going to wake up this morning to the news that they had a new contract.
And they actually are very disappointed.
They don't want to be on strike.
And they were hoping that the contract negotiations were going to end up being settled within the next few days.
Is the union prepared for a long strike?
The union is.
And we're talking about the national organization of the United Auto Workers union.
Yes.
They have a large strike fund, and they are ready to pay.
But remember, these workers, their strike pay is $200 a week.
So these workers are obviously not looking forward to trying to make ends meet on $200.
And have you talked to any of them?
Have they told you their plans to get by?
I think they're trying to pin their hopes on the fact that the strike will not last long.
I mean, they're very concerned.
I talked to one gentleman who said, you know, it may sound to other people like this is an argument over money.
But for him, he has a special needs son and he says this isn't an argument over money.
This is an argument over paying my son's medical bills.
And it's very personal.
And I don't care if I have to struggle to get by.
I'm going to stand firm.
And what about General Motors?
How well prepared are they with, you know, all of their workers walking out?
That's the big question.
I mean, I would imagine there's a lot of analysts sort of scratching their heads, wondering whether or not GM is prepared for this kind of thing.
If you remember, there was a strike in 1998, nearly 10 years ago, that affected GM.
That lasted for 54 days, and it cost the company more than $3 billion, and that's money that GM certainly cannot afford to lose right now.
So I would imagine that both General Motors and the UAW have serious intentions to get things worked out.
I don't think any of them want this strike to last very long.
And Celeste, just real briefly, this is a strike that mainly is over health care, correct?
That's absolutely right, that GM wants to establish a health care trust fund; the UAW says that's fine as long as you give us job security.
And there's the sticking point.
That's NPR's Celeste Headlee speaking to us from outside the GM plant in Detroit.
We'll have more on this story later on in the program.
The top U.S.
commander in Iraq, General David Petraeus, will arrive on Capitol Hill Monday, facing a Congress that includes a number of skeptics.
Two reports on Iraq issued this week did not paint a rosy picture, and Petraeus has to convince Congress his strategy is working.
That's if the Pentagon hopes to win an additional $50 billion to continue the war through the spring.
NPR's defense correspondent Guy Raz has a preview.
What's long been described as the Petraeus report is now being referred to by the Pentagon as the Petraeus assessment.
There's a reason why.
General Petraeus won't actually be writing anything down; he'll arrive to Capitol Hill Monday armed with a stack of statistics and charts.
Later in the week, the White House will put his testimony and the testimony of U.S.
Ambassador Ryan Crocker into a written report for Congress.
Now, according to sources in the Pentagon and in Iraq, Petraeus will suggest a modest U.S.
troop reduction in Iraq beginning early next year.
But any proposed reduction won't necessarily be tied to security conditions in Iraq.
The reductions are actually scheduled to happen anyway because starting next April the Army and the Marines run out of ready brigades to replace the ones scheduled to rotate out of Iraq.
The first surge brigade, that's about 4,000 troops, arrived in Iraq last February, and each soldier now serves a 15-month tour.
So add 15 months to February and you get to April 2008.
Every month after that, another brigade is scheduled to rotate out until October 2008, when the total number of U.S.
troops in Iraq will return to the pre-surge level of 130,000.
And Pentagon officials believe the Army and the Marines can sustain that level of troops in Iraq for several more years.
Guy Raz, NPR News, the Pentagon.
We're going to start this morning in Yemen because there was another terrible turn in the war there yesterday.
